original.title: Book II: The Ring of Gyges
original.preview: Glaucon: Socrates, do you wish really to persuade us, or only to seem to have persuaded us, that to be just is always better than to be unjust?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, do you wish really to persuade us, or only to seem to have persuaded us, that to be just is always better than to be unjust?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I should wish really to persuade you, if I could.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then you certainly have not succeeded. Let me ask you now: How would you arrange goods—are there not some which we welcome for their own sakes, and independently of their consequences, as, for example, harmless pleasures and enjoyments?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I agree in thinking that there is such a class.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Is there not also a second class of goods, such as knowledge, sight, health, which are desirable not only in themselves, but also for their results?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And would you not recognize a third class, such as gymnastic, and the care of the sick, and the physician's art—these do us good but we regard them as disagreeable; and no one would choose them for their own sakes, but only for the sake of some reward?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is this third class also. But why do you ask?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Because I want to know in which of the three classes you would place justice?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the highest class—among those goods which he who would be happy desires both for their own sake and for the sake of their results.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then the many are of another mind; they think that justice is to be reckoned in the troublesome class, among goods which are to be pursued for the sake of rewards and of reputation, but in themselves are disagreeable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I know that this is their manner of thinking. But I am too stupid to be convinced by Thrasymachus.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I wish that you would hear me as well as him. For Thrasymachus seems to me, like a snake, to have been charmed by your voice sooner than he ought to have been; but to my mind the nature of justice and injustice have not yet been made clear.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Setting aside their rewards and results, I want to know what they are in themselves, and how they inwardly work in the soul. I will revive the argument of Thrasymachus.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: First I will speak of the nature and origin of justice according to the common view. Secondly, I will show that all men who practise justice do so against their will, of necessity. And thirdly, I will argue that the life of the unjust is after all better far than the life of the just.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Indeed I do approve of your proposal; nor can I imagine any theme about which a man of sense would oftener wish to converse.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They say that to do injustice is, by nature, good; to suffer injustice, evil; but that the evil is greater than the good. And so when men have both done and suffered injustice, they think that they had better agree among themselves to have neither.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Hence there arise laws and mutual covenants; and that which is ordained by law is termed lawful and just. This is the origin and nature of justice—it is a mean or compromise, between the best of all, which is to do injustice and not be punished, and the worst of all, which is to suffer injustice without retaliation.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now that those who practise justice do so involuntarily and because they have not the power to be unjust will best appear if we imagine something of this kind: having given both to the just and the unjust power to do what they will, let us watch and see whither desire will lead them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The liberty which we are supposing may be most completely given to them in the form of such a power as is said to have been possessed by Gyges the ancestor of Croesus the Lydian. According to the tradition, Gyges was a shepherd in the service of the king of Lydia.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There was a great storm, and an earthquake made an opening in the earth at the place where he was feeding his flock. Amazed at the sight, he descended into the opening, where, among other marvels, he beheld a hollow brazen horse, having doors.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He stooped and looking in saw a dead body of stature more than human, and having nothing on but a gold ring; this he took from the finger of the dead and reascended.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now the shepherds met together to send their monthly report to the king. He came having the ring on his finger, and as he was sitting among them he chanced to turn the collet of the ring inside his hand, when instantly he became invisible.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He was astonished at this, and again touching the ring he turned the collet outwards and reappeared; he made several trials of the ring, and always with the same result.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Whereupon he contrived to be chosen one of the messengers who were sent to the court; where as soon as he arrived he seduced the queen, and with her help conspired against the king and slew him, and took the kingdom.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Suppose now that there were two such magic rings, and the just put on one of them and the unjust the other; no man can be imagined to be of such an iron nature that he would stand fast in justice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No man would keep his hands off what was not his own when he could safely take what he liked out of the market, or go into houses and lie with any one at his pleasure, or kill or release from prison whom he would, and in all respects be like a God among men.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Then the actions of the just would be as the actions of the unjust; they would both come at last to the same point. And this we may truly affirm to be a great proof that a man is just, not willingly or because he thinks that justice is any good to him individually, but of necessity.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Heavens! my dear Glaucon, how energetically you polish them up for the decision, first one and then the other, as if they were two statues.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I do my best. And now that we know what they are like there is no difficulty in tracing out the sort of life which awaits either of them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Socrates, you do not suppose that there is nothing more to be urged?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Why, what else is there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The strongest point of all has not been even mentioned.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, then, according to the proverb, 'Let brother help brother'—if he fails in any part do you assist him; although I must confess that Glaucon has already said quite enough to lay me in the dust.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nonsense. But let me add something more: There is another side to Glaucon's argument about the praise and censure of justice and injustice.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Parents and tutors are always telling their sons and their wards that they are to be just; but why? Not for the sake of justice, but for the sake of character and reputation.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The universal voice of mankind is always declaring that justice and virtue are honourable, but grievous and toilsome; and that the pleasures of vice and injustice are easy of attainment, and are only censured by law and opinion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They say also that honesty is for the most part less profitable than dishonesty; and they are quite ready to call wicked men happy, and to honour them both in public and private when they are rich or in any other way influential.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But most extraordinary of all is their mode of speaking about virtue and the gods: they say that the gods apportion calamity and misery to many good men, and good and happiness to the wicked.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: And mendicant prophets go to rich men's doors and persuade them that they have a power committed to them by the gods of making an atonement for sins by sacrifices or charms, with rejoicings and feasts.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The cause of all this was indicated by us at the beginning: no one has ever adequately described the true essential nature of either of them abiding in the soul, and invisible to any human or divine eye.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No one has shown that of all the things of a man's soul which he has within him, justice is the greatest good, and injustice the greatest evil.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Show not only the superiority which justice has over injustice, but what effect they have on the possessor of them which makes the one to be a good and the other an evil to him. And please exclude reputations.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I had always admired the genius of Glaucon and Adeimantus, but on hearing these words I was quite delighted. Sons of an illustrious father, that was not a bad beginning of the Elegiac verses which the admirer made in honour of you: 'Sons of Ariston, divine offspring of an illustrious hero.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There is something truly divine in being able to argue as you have done for the superiority of injustice, and remaining unconvinced by your own arguments.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I am in a strait between two; on the one hand I feel that I am unequal to the task. And yet I cannot refuse to help, while breath and speech remain to me; I am afraid that there would be an impiety in being present when justice is evil spoken of and not lifting up a hand in her defence.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Seeing then that we are no great wits, I think that we had better adopt a method which I may illustrate thus: suppose that a short-sighted person had been asked to read small letters from a distance; and it occurred to some one else that they might be found in another place which was larger.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true; but how does the illustration apply to our enquiry?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Justice, which is the subject of our enquiry, is sometimes spoken of as the virtue of an individual, and sometimes as the virtue of a State. And is not a State larger than an individual?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: It is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then in the larger the quantity of justice is likely to be larger and more easily discernible. I propose therefore that we enquire into the nature of justice and injustice, first as they appear in the State, and secondly in the individual.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is an excellent proposal.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And if we imagine the State in process of creation, we shall see the justice and injustice of the State in process of creation also.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I dare say.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A State arises, as I conceive, out of the needs of mankind; no one is self-sufficing, but all of us have many wants. Can any other origin of a State be imagined?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: There can be no other.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then, as we have many wants, and many persons are needed to supply them, one takes a helper for one purpose and another for another; and when these partners and helpers are gathered together in one habitation the body of inhabitants is termed a State.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And they exchange with one another, and one gives, and another receives, under the idea that the exchange will be for their good.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then let us begin and create in idea a State; and yet the true creator is necessity, who is the mother of our invention.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Now the first and greatest of necessities is food, which is the condition of life and existence. The second is a dwelling, and the third clothing and the like.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now let us see how our city will be able to supply this great demand: We may suppose that one man is a husbandman, another a builder, some one else a weaver—shall we add to them a shoemaker?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Quite right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And will you have a work better done when the workman has many occupations, or when he has only one?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When he has only one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then more than four citizens will be required; for the husbandman will not make his own plough or mattock, if they are to be good for anything. Neither will the builder make his tools—and he too needs many.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then carpenters, and smiths, and many other artisans, will be sharers in our little State, which is already beginning to grow.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then there must be another class of citizens who will bring the required supply from another city. And if the trader goes empty-handed, he will come back empty-handed.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That is certain.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we shall want merchants. And if merchandise is to be carried over the sea, skilful sailors will also be needed, and in considerable numbers.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, in considerable numbers.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now, Adeimantus, is our State matured and perfected?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Where, then, is justice, and where is injustice, and in what part of the State did they spring up?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably in the dealings of these citizens with one another. I cannot imagine that they are more likely to be found anywhere else.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let us then consider what will be their way of life. They will produce corn, and wine, and clothes, and shoes, and build houses for themselves. They will work, in summer, commonly stripped and barefoot, but in winter substantially clothed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They will feed on barley-meal and flour of wheat, baking noble cakes and loaves; these they will serve up on a mat of reeds or on clean leaves, themselves reclining upon beds strewn with yew or myrtle.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, Socrates, and if you were providing for a city of pigs, how else would you feed the beasts?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But what would you have, Glaucon?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Why, you should give them the ordinary conveniences of life. People who are to be comfortable are accustomed to lie on sofas, and dine off tables, and they should have sauces and sweets in the modern style.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, now I understand: the question which you would have me consider is, not only how a State, but how a luxurious State is created. In my opinion the true and healthy constitution of the State is the one which I have described. But if you wish also to see a State at fever heat, I have no objection.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: For I suspect that many will not be satisfied with the simpler way. They will be for adding sofas, and tables, and other furniture; also dainties, and perfumes, and incense, and courtesans, and cakes, all these not of one sort only, but in every variety.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we must enlarge our borders; for the original healthy State is no longer sufficient. Now will the city have to fill and swell with a multitude of callings which are not required by any natural want.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And living in this way we shall have much greater need of physicians than before.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Much greater.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the country which was enough to support the original inhabitants will be too small now, and not enough?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then a slice of our neighbours' land will be wanted by us for pasture and tillage, and they will want a slice of ours, if, like ourselves, they exceed the limit of necessity.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That, Socrates, will be inevitable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so we shall go to war, Glaucon. Shall we not?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Most certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then without determining as yet whether war does good or harm, thus much we may affirm, that now we have discovered war to be derived from causes which are also the causes of almost all the evils in States, private as well as public.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Undoubtedly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And our State must once more enlarge; and this time the enlargement will be nothing short of a whole army, which will have to go out and fight with the invaders for all that we have.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Why? Are they not capable of defending themselves?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: No, not if we were right in the principle which was acknowledged by all of us when we were framing the State: the principle was that one man cannot practise many arts with success.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But is not war an art?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And an art requiring as much attention as shoemaking?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the higher the duties of the guardian, the more time, and skill, and art, and application will be needed by him.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Will he not also require natural aptitude for his calling?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then it will be our duty to select, if we can, natures which are fitted for the task of guarding the city.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: It will.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Is not the noble youth very like a well-bred dog in respect of guarding and watching?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I mean that both of them ought to be quick to see, and swift to overtake the enemy when they see him; and strong too if, when they have caught him, they have to fight with him.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: All these qualities will certainly be required by them.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is he likely to be brave who has no spirit? Have you never observed how invincible and unconquerable is spirit and how the presence of it makes the soul of any creature to be absolutely fearless?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I have.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But are not these spirited natures apt to be savage with one another, and with everybody else?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: A difficulty by no means easy to overcome.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whereas they ought to be dangerous to their enemies, and gentle to their friends; if not, they will destroy themselves without waiting for their enemies to destroy them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What is to be done then? How shall we find a gentle nature which has also a great spirit, for the one is the contradiction of the other?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Many animals furnish examples of them; our friend the dog is a very good one: you know that well-bred dogs are perfectly gentle to their familiars and acquaintances, and the reverse to strangers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I know.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Would not he who is fitted to be a guardian, besides the spirited nature, need to have the qualities of a philosopher?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I do not apprehend your meaning.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The trait of which I am speaking may be also seen in the dog, and is remarkable in the animal. A dog, whenever he sees a stranger, is angry; when an acquaintance, he welcomes him, although the one has never done him any harm, nor the other any good.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The matter never struck me before; but I quite recognise the truth of your remark.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And surely this instinct of the dog is very charming;—your dog is a true philosopher. Because he distinguishes the face of a friend and of an enemy only by the criterion of knowing and not knowing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Most assuredly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is not the love of learning the love of wisdom, which is philosophy? And may we not say confidently of man also, that he who is likely to be gentle to his friends and acquaintances, must by nature be a lover of wisdom and knowledge?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That we may safely affirm.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then he who is to be a really good and noble guardian of the State will require to unite in himself philosophy and spirit and swiftness and strength.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Undoubtedly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we have found the desired natures; and now that we have found them, how are they to be reared and educated? Is not this enquiry which may be expected to throw light on the greater enquiry which is our final end—How do justice and injustice grow up in States?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The enquiry would be of great service to us.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the task must not be given up, even if somewhat long. Come then, and let us pass a leisure hour in story-telling, and our story shall be the education of our heroes.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: By all means.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what shall be their education? Can we find a better than the traditional sort?—and this has two divisions, gymnastic for the body, and music for the soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Shall we begin education with music, and go on to gymnastic afterwards? And when you speak of music, do you include literature or not?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And literature may be either true or false?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You know that we begin by telling children stories which, though not wholly destitute of truth, are in the main fictitious; and these stories are told them when they are not of an age to learn gymnastics.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You know also that the beginning is the most important part of any work, especially in the case of a young and tender thing; for that is the time at which the character is being formed and the desired impression is more readily taken.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And shall we just carelessly allow children to hear any casual tales which may be devised by casual persons, and to receive into their minds ideas for the most part the very opposite of those which we should wish them to have when they are grown up?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We cannot.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then the first thing will be to establish a censorship of the writers of fiction, and let the censors receive any tale of fiction which is good, and reject the bad; and we will desire mothers and nurses to tell their children the authorised ones only.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of what tales are you speaking?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Those which are narrated by Homer and Hesiod, and the rest of the poets, who have ever been the great story-tellers of mankind.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But which stories do you mean, and what fault do you find with them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A fault which is most serious: the fault of telling a lie, and, what is more, a bad lie.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But when is this fault committed?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whenever an erroneous representation is made of the nature of gods and heroes—as when a painter paints a portrait not having the shadow of a likeness to the original.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, that sort of thing is certainly very blamable; but what are the stories which you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First of all, there was that greatest of all lies which the poet told about Uranus, and what Hesiod says that Uranus did, and how Cronus retaliated on him. The doings of Cronus, and the sufferings which in turn his son inflicted upon him, even if they were true, ought certainly not to be lightly told to young and thoughtless persons.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Why, yes, those stories are extremely objectionable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yes, Adeimantus, they are stories not to be repeated in our State; the young man should not be told that in committing the worst of crimes he is far from doing anything outrageous; and that even if he chastises his father when he does wrong, he will only be following the example of the first and greatest among the gods.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I entirely agree with you; in my opinion those stories are quite unfit to be repeated.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: God is always to be represented as he truly is, whatever be the sort of poetry. And is he not truly good? And must he not be represented as such?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And no good thing is hurtful? And that which is not hurtful hurts not? And that which hurts not does no evil?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It follows therefore that the good is not the cause of all things, but of the good only. Then God, if he be good, is not the author of all things, as the many assert, but he is the cause of a few things only.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That appears to me to be most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let this then be one of our rules and principles concerning the gods, to which our poets and reciters will be expected to conform—that God is not the author of all things, but of good only.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That will do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And what do you think of a second principle? Shall I ask you whether God is a magician, and of a nature to appear insidiously now in one shape, and now in another? Or is he one and the same immutably fixed in his own proper image?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I cannot answer you without more thought.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well, things which are at their best are also least liable to be altered or discomposed; for example, when healthiest and strongest, the human frame is least liable to be affected by meats and drinks. And the same principle applies to God and the things of God: they are in every way perfect.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course they are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then it is impossible that God should ever be willing to change; being, as is supposed, the fairest and best that is conceivable, every god remains absolutely and for ever in his own form.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That necessarily follows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then is God perfectly simple and true both in word and deed; he changes not; he deceives not, either by sign or word, by dream or waking vision.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Your thoughts are the reflection of my own.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: You agree with me then that this is the second type or form in which we should write and speak about divine things. The gods are not magicians who transform themselves, neither do they deceive mankind in any way.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I grant that. I entirely agree in these principles, and promise to make them my laws.

modern.title: Book II: The Ring Thing
modern.preview: Glaucon: Socrates, do you actually want to convince us that being just is always better than being unjust, or are you just trying to look like you convinced us?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Socrates, do you actually want to convince us that being just is always better than being unjust, or are you just trying to look like you convinced us?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I'd really want to convince you, if I could.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Well then you totally failed. Let me ask you this: aren't there some things we want just for themselves—harmless pleasures that feel good in the moment even though nothing comes from them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, I think there's definitely that category.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And then there's a second category, like knowledge, sight, health—things that are good both for themselves AND for what they lead to?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And wouldn't you also recognize a third category, like going to the gym or various ways of making money—stuff that's good for us but we find it unpleasant? No one would choose them for their own sake, only for the rewards.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, there's that third category too. But why are you asking?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Because I want to know which of these three categories you'd put justice in.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: In the highest category—among those good things that anyone who wants to be happy would want both for their own sake and for their results.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Well most people disagree with you. They think justice belongs in the annoying category—stuff you pursue for the rewards and reputation, but that's actually unpleasant.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I know that's how they think. But I'm too dense to be convinced by Thrasymachus.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I want you to hear me out too. I think Thrasymachus gave up too easily when you charmed him with your words—but I don't think the nature of justice and injustice has actually been made clear yet.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Setting aside rewards and consequences, I want to know what they actually ARE, and how they work inside someone's soul. So let me revive Thrasymachus's argument.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: First, I'll explain the nature and origin of justice according to popular opinion. Second, I'll show that everyone who acts justly does it against their will. And third, I'll argue an unjust life is way better than a just one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I definitely approve of your proposal. I can't think of any topic a reasonable person would want to discuss more often.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: People say that doing injustice is naturally good, but suffering injustice is bad—and the bad outweighs the good. So when people have experienced both, they figure it's better to agree to have neither.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's where laws and mutual agreements come from. What's ordained by law gets called 'lawful' and 'just.' This is justice's origin—it's a compromise between the best scenario (doing injustice without punishment) and the worst (suffering injustice without retaliation).

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The best way to show that people only act justly because they don't have the power to be unjust is to imagine this: give both just and unjust people the power to do whatever they want, then watch where their desires lead them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: We can give them complete freedom through a power like what Gyges supposedly had—you know, the ancestor of Croesus. The story goes that Gyges was a shepherd working for the king of Lydia.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: There was this massive storm and earthquake that cracked open the ground where he was grazing his flock. Amazed, he climbed down into the opening and found all these crazy things, including a hollow bronze horse with doors.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He looked inside and saw a dead body that seemed larger than human, wearing nothing but a gold ring. He took the ring from the corpse and climbed back out.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: At the shepherds' monthly meeting, he accidentally turned the ring's setting toward his palm—and instantly became invisible! The others started talking about him like he wasn't there.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: He experimented with the ring. Same result every time—turn the setting inward and disappear, turn it outward and reappear.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: So he arranged to become a messenger to the royal court. As soon as he got there, he seduced the queen, and together they plotted against the king, killed him, and took over the kingdom.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Now imagine there were two such magic rings—one for a just person and one for an unjust person. No one could possibly be so rigid that they'd stick to justice.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No one would keep their hands off other people's stuff when they could safely take whatever they wanted—basically be like a god among humans.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The 'just' person would act exactly like the unjust one. This proves that people are only just out of necessity, not because they think justice is actually good for them personally.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Wow! Glaucon, you're really polishing up both sides of this argument like they're statues or something.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I'm doing my best. And now that we know what they're like, it's easy to trace out what kind of life each one would have.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Socrates, you don't think there's nothing more to add to this argument, do you?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What else is there?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The strongest point hasn't even been mentioned yet.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Well then, 'let brother help brother' as they say—if Glaucon's missing something, you help him out. Though I have to say Glaucon has already said enough to completely destroy me.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Nonsense. But let me add something: There's another side to Glaucon's argument about how people praise and criticize justice and injustice.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Parents and teachers are always telling their kids to be just—but why? Not for justice's sake, but for reputation and character.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Everyone's always saying justice and virtue are honorable, but difficult and exhausting, while the pleasures of vice and injustice are easy to get and only criticized by law and public opinion.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: They say honesty usually pays less than dishonesty. They're willing to call wicked people happy and honor them when they're rich or influential.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: But here's the most extraordinary thing: they say the gods give disaster and misery to many good people, while giving good fortune to wicked people.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: These fortune-tellers go to rich people's houses convincing them they can fix sins through sacrifices and rituals. They promise to hurt enemies using magic.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: The problem is this: no one has ever properly described what justice and injustice actually do in someone's soul, by themselves, whether gods and humans see it or not.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No one has shown that injustice is the greatest evil a soul can contain, and justice the greatest good.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Don't just show us that justice is better than injustice—show us what each one does to the person who has it that makes one bad and the other good.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: I've always admired you two, but hearing this I'm absolutely delighted. That poem about you after the battle of Megara got it right: 'Sons of Ariston, divine offspring of an illustrious hero.'

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: There's something truly divine about being able to argue so well for injustice while remaining unconvinced by your own arguments.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But that makes this harder for me. I'm stuck between two problems: I feel unequal to the task, since you weren't satisfied with my answer to Thrasymachus. But I can't refuse to help either—it would be wrong to hear justice attacked and not defend it.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: This inquiry is serious and will require really good vision. Since we're not the brightest, I think we should try a different method.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: It's like if someone with bad eyesight was asked to read small letters from far away, but then someone noticed the same letters written larger somewhere else. Reading the big letters first would be lucky, right?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True, but how does this apply to our question?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Justice can exist in an individual person and also in a state. And a state is larger than a person, right?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yeah.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So in the larger thing, justice might be more obvious and easier to see. I suggest we look for justice in the state first, then in the individual, going from bigger to smaller.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's an excellent idea.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: If we imagine a state being created, we can watch justice and injustice being created too.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: A state exists because people have needs. No one is self-sufficient—we all have many needs. Can you imagine any other reason for a state to exist?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: No other reason.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So people take helpers for different purposes, and when these partners and helpers live together, we call that group of inhabitants a state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And they trade with each other, giving and receiving, thinking the exchange will benefit them.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then let's start building our imaginary state. The real creator is necessity—the mother of invention.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The first and most important necessity is food—the condition for life and existence. Second is shelter, third is clothing.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Right.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So how will our city supply this demand? We'll need a farmer, a builder, a weaver. Should we add a shoemaker?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Makes sense.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Will work be better done when the worker has many occupations, or just one?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When they have just one.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we'll need more than four people. The farmer won't make their own plow or tools if they're going to be good. Neither will the builder. So carpenters, smiths, and many other craftspeople will join our little state.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: We'll also need traders who bring supplies from other cities. And merchants, and sailors if goods go by sea.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Yes, in considerable numbers.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And now, Adeimantus, is our state complete?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I think so.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Where, then, is justice? And where is injustice? In what part of the state did they spring up?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Probably in how these citizens deal with one another.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let's think about their way of life. They'll grow food, make wine, build houses, make clothes. They'll eat simple meals on mats or leaves, lying on beds of myrtle, feasting and singing hymns.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: And if you were providing for a city of pigs, how else would you feed them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What would you have, Glaucon?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: The ordinary conveniences of life! Sofas, tables, sauces and sweets in the modern style.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Ah, I see. You want me to consider not just how a state is created, but how a luxurious state is created. Fair enough. In my opinion the true healthy constitution is what I just described. But if you want to see a state at fever heat, I have no objection.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Many won't be satisfied with simple living. They'll want sofas, tables, fancy furniture, perfumes, incense, courtesans, cakes—not of one sort only, but in every variety.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we must enlarge our borders. The original healthy state won't be big enough. We'll need a multitude of callings not required by natural want—hunters, actors, poets, dancers, musicians, tutors, nurses, barbers, cooks.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Living this way, we'll need way more doctors than before.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Much more.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And the land that was enough for the original inhabitants will be too small now.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So we'll want a slice of our neighbors' land for pasture and farmland. And they'll want a slice of ours, if they've also gone beyond necessity into unlimited accumulation of wealth.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That, Socrates, will be inevitable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And so we shall go to war. Shall we not?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Most certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Without yet deciding whether war does good or harm, we can say this: we've discovered that war comes from the same causes that produce almost all the evils in states, public and private.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Undoubtedly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So our state must grow again—this time we need a whole army to fight invaders and protect everything we have.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Why? Can't the citizens defend themselves?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: No, not if we stick to our principle that one person can't practice many arts successfully.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But isn't war an art?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And one that requires as much attention as shoemaking?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The higher the duties of the guardian, the more time, skill, and dedication they'll need.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: No doubt.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Won't they need natural aptitude too?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then it's our duty to select natures fit for guarding the city.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: It is.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Isn't a noble youth very like a well-bred dog when it comes to guarding and watching?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: What do you mean?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Both need to be quick to see enemies, swift to chase them, and strong enough to fight when they catch them.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: All those qualities will definitely be needed.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: And is someone likely to be brave without spirit? Have you noticed how invincible spirit makes any creature—absolutely fearless?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I have.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: But aren't spirited natures apt to be savage with everyone, including each other?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: That's a difficulty not easily overcome.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: They need to be dangerous to enemies, but gentle to friends. Otherwise they'll destroy themselves before their enemies get the chance.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: How do we find a gentle nature that also has great spirit? They seem like opposites.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: They do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Many animals combine them. Dogs are a great example—they're perfectly gentle with familiar people but fierce with strangers.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Yes, I know.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Besides being spirited, wouldn't a good guardian also need to be philosophical?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I don't follow.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Think about it. A dog gets angry at strangers and welcomes acquaintances—even though neither has done them any harm or good. The dog distinguishes friend from foe purely by knowing vs. not knowing.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: I never noticed that, but it's true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That's pretty charming. Your dog is a true philosopher! They judge by knowledge, not by experience of benefit or harm. And isn't the love of learning the love of wisdom—philosophy?

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Absolutely.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So someone who's going to be gentle to friends and acquaintances must be a lover of wisdom and knowledge by nature.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: We can safely say that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then a really good guardian of the state will need to combine philosophy, spirit, speed, and strength.

messages.speaker: Glaucon
messages.text: Undoubtedly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Great, we've found the natures we need. Now how should they be raised and educated? This inquiry might help with our main question: how do justice and injustice grow up in states?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: This would be very helpful.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then we shouldn't give up, even if it takes a while. Let's tell stories—about the education of our heroes.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: By all means.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: What should their education be? Can we beat the traditional sort? It has two parts: gymnastics for the body and music for the soul.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Should we start with music and do gymnastics later? And when I say 'music,' do I mean literature too?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: You do.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Literature can be true or false. We tell children stories—mostly fiction with some truth—before they're old enough for physical training.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Very true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The beginning of any work is the most important part, especially for young, impressionable minds. That's when character is formed and impressions stick.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Quite true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Should we just let kids hear any random stories from any random people? They might absorb ideas completely opposite to what we'd want them to believe as adults.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: We can't allow that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: First thing: set up censorship for fiction writers. Accept good stories, reject bad ones. Mothers and nurses should only tell authorized stories.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: What stories are you talking about?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The ones told by Homer, Hesiod, and the other great poets.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Which ones? What's wrong with them?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: The most serious fault: telling lies. Bad lies.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: When do they do that?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Whenever they misrepresent the nature of gods and heroes—like a painter making a portrait that looks nothing like the original.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That's definitely wrong. But which stories specifically?

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: That story about Uranus and what Cronus did to him, and what Zeus did to Cronus—even if true, shouldn't be told casually to young people. If they must be mentioned, only a few should hear them in secret mysteries.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Those stories are extremely objectionable.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Yeah, Adeimantus. Stories not to be repeated in our state. Young people shouldn't hear that committing terrible crimes is following the example of the greatest gods.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I completely agree. Those stories are unfit to be told.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: God should always be represented as he truly is. And isn't he truly good? Must he not be shown as good?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Certainly.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Nothing good is harmful. What isn't harmful doesn't hurt. What doesn't hurt does no evil.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: True.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So the good isn't the cause of everything—only of good things. God, being good, isn't the author of everything as many claim, but only the cause of a few things. The evils must come from somewhere else.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That seems most true.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Let this be our first rule about the gods: poets and storytellers must show that God is not the author of all things, but only of good.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That works.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Here's a second principle: Is God a shape-shifter, appearing in different forms at different times? Or is he one and the same, unchangeable in his own true form?

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I need to think about that.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Consider this: things at their best are least affected by outside influences. A healthy body is least affected by food and drink. A strong plant suffers least from wind or sun. The same principle applies to God and divine things—they're perfect in every way.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Of course they are.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: Then it's impossible that God would ever want to change. Being the fairest and best conceivable, every god remains absolutely and forever in his own form.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: That necessarily follows.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: God is perfectly simple and true in word and deed. He doesn't change. He doesn't deceive—not through signs, words, dreams, or visions.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: Your thoughts match my own.

messages.speaker: Socrates
messages.text: So you agree this is our second rule about divine things: the gods don't shapeshift, and they don't deceive humans in any way.

messages.speaker: Adeimantus
messages.text: I agree completely, and I'll make these my laws.
